steps.title: Mix the water and milk into the pot.
steps.content: Mix the water and milk into the pot. For each cup of milk, match it with a cup of water i.e. one cup of milk, one cup of water. Should you prefer to have a thinner percentage of milk, you can simply adjust the ratio to 1 part milk and 2 parts water. [1] X Research source If you want that “kick” in your tea, you will add a small serving of tea masala to infuse with the mixture at this first stage. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Set it up on the stove and bring the mixture to a boil.
steps.content: Set it up on the stove and bring the mixture to a boil. Some folks add sugar/sweetener to the boiling mix before serving. However, if you have a guest who does not take sugar, you may want to hold off on adding it. [3] X Research source Also, this is the point where “nylon” is created – nylon is the boiled mixture of water and milk that can be used to make hot chocolate or instant coffee/tea.

steps.title: Turn off the heat before the mixture boils over the pot.
steps.content: Turn off the heat before the mixture boils over the pot.

steps.title: Add a spoonful of tea leaves and stir to mix it all around.
steps.content: Add a spoonful of tea leaves and stir to mix it all around. At my house, we would rather do this rather than let the tea leaves boil together with the nylon because it can make the tea too strong. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Cover the pot and wait 3-5 minutes.
steps.content: Cover the pot and wait 3-5 minutes.

steps.title: Filter into a thermos, teapot or jug using a tea strainer/sieve.
steps.content: Filter into a thermos, teapot or jug using a tea strainer/sieve. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Pour into a cup, add sweetener, cinnamon, and enjoy your chai!
steps.content: Pour into a cup, add sweetener, cinnamon, and enjoy your chai!
